stem: A 38-year-old weightlifter reports forearm pain and paresthesias in the thumb, index, and middle fingers that worsen with resisted pronation. Phalen and Tinel tests at the wrist are negative. Which structure most likely compresses the involved nerve?

choices.A: Between the heads of pronator teres
choices.E: Within the axilla beneath the pectoralis minor

rationale_correct: Pronator syndrome entraps the median nerve between the humeral and ulnar heads of pronator teres, producing exertional forearm pain and median territory paresthesias without nocturnal symptoms.

rationale_distractors.B: Compression under the flexor retinaculum causes classic carpal tunnel symptoms aggravated at night and positive wrist provocative tests.
rationale_distractors.C: Cubital tunnel compression affects the ulnar nerve, leading to ring and little finger symptoms.
rationale_distractors.D: Guyon canal lesions also involve the ulnar nerve at the wrist, not median distribution.
rationale_distractors.E: Axillary compression beneath pectoralis minor would compromise the cords of the brachial plexus with more global deficits.
